Antonius first,  and Pompey afterwards,  received a commission to fight the pirates,  his 'provincia' was,  geographically,  something dÜFerent : it was,  apart from the sea itself,  an area ( up to fifty miles inland from the Mediterranean ) in any part of which he might excercise his 'Imperium' for certain purposes only,  and only if the necessity arose.  There was the danger here of a conflict between the imperium of Antonius ( or Pompey ) and the imperium of the governor of any province bordering on the Mediterranean.  In Pompey's case,  there were two instances of such conflict.  The lesson of this was that,  if another great proconsular command was created,  its holder's imperium^ as against that of the normal provincial governor's,  should be not aequum^ but maius^ as Cicero suggested for Cassius in 43 B.  C.  { PhiL XI,  30 ).  When this was suggested in the case of Pompey's Cura annonae in 57 B.  C. ,  people did not like it { Att,  IV,  i,  7 ).  It is therefore hard to follow Geber in his belief ( which has no ancient evidence to support it ) that Pompey was given maius imperium by the Lex Manilia of 66 B.  C. 
Geker,  like many other historians,  sees the conferring of Caesar's great command in j 9 B.  C.  from the point of view of the current political situation at Rome rather than in the light of a formidable danger which was developing on the northern frontiers and he believes with Suetonius { Divus luliuSy 19,  2 ) that,  with pathetic futility,  the Senate was capable,  in 60 B.  C. ,  of naming 'silvae callesque' as consular provinces and expecting,  by this device,  to prevent Caesar from governing a respectable province.  The truth appears to me to be very different,  as I suggested in Journal of Roman Studies^ XXIX ( 1939 ),  180—3.  Nor,  for reasons which I gave in my articles in /.  R,  S. ,  XXIX,  do I accept,  as Gelzer accepts,  Mommsen's view of the Rechtsfrage'.  But,  as concerns the sequence of events in 50 B.  C.  and Pompey's place in them,  his sanguine belief up to the moment when A.  Hirtius came to Rome from Caesar's camp and made no attempt to see him,  that Caesar did not really want war,  and his acceptance,  for the last time,  of a commission 'to save the State',  I find myself in the fullest agreement with Gelzer's fast - moving and vivid narrative. 
Exeter College^ Oxford, 
/.  P,  F.  D,  Balsdon,
